section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need the reply Vocabulary Card from Day 1 and today’s Activity Cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Preschool Time and learned about how Suzy Sue’s friends searched for her, but there was no reply.
When we reply to someone, we answer them. The animals called for Suzy Sue, but there was no reply. No one answered.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use reply Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at different ways you can reply to someone. Let’s look at the cards to figure out how each person is replying.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card, and then ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge and support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the card to extend the conversation and to get the children talking.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Replying Invite children to talk about all of the different ways that people can reply. Encourage children to discuss situations where they would raise their hands, write a letter, send a text message, call someone on the phone, or give a thumbs-up to reply to a friend.
Review each picture encouraging children to describe what they see in the picture. Ask what they think the person in the picture is doing.
Encourage children to imagine that they are the person in the picture. What would they say/text/write?

Children who speak Spanish may recognize the word text because it is a cognate and sounds the same in Spanish. Children may need help, however, with the expression thumbs-up. Explain the difference between a thumbs-up and a thumbs-down.

Preschoolers need to learn how to sustain attention during classroom activities. You can encourage paying attention by repeating the questions on each card and asking children to repeat the question. Improving children’s receptive vocabulary (listening comprehension) will help them sustain attention. Try to increase children’s vocabulary each week, using new vocabulary every day and providing safe opportunities to use those words on their own.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Preschool Time. There are a lot of really big words in the story that will be fun to act out.
In this activity, we will pretend (make believe) that we are all actors. We will act out different sentences from the story.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Act out this sentence from the story for your students: “‘The child’s gone to preschool,’ she said with a sigh.” (page 6).

Act Out and Say the Sentence Show children the following sentences in Preschool Time. Then encourage them to act out each sentence, repeating the sentence after you: “Her friends searched the hen house.” (page 4); “They searched all over, high and low.” (page 5); “She crossed her front legs and put on a glum face.” (page 6); “‘Don’t be so sure,’ grumbled the cow.” (page 10); “The horse gasped, ‘Oh no!’” (page 12); “The hens threw themselves in a heartbroken heap.” (page 25); and “‘. . . we’ll never see you!’ they cried in dismay.” (page 26).

Talk About It Invite children to act out other scenes they remember from the book. They can pretend they are one of the characters and act out one of the pages in the book. For example, children can act out the scene with the animals on the playground to make the activity more lively.

If children are having difficulty saying some of the sentences, make two shorter sentences. For example: “They searched all over, high and low.” can be “They searched all over.” and “They searched high and low.” You can also simplify the challenging vocabulary words.
Encourage more advanced learners to act out the sentences in multiple ways. Have children say the sentence, then act it out in two different ways.

Acting out vocabulary and phrases is a great way for multilingual learners to accelerate their English language proficiency. Learning new vocabulary and phrases when accompanied by physical actions is a successful strategy known as Total Physical Response.
Preschoolers may not produce all speech sounds correctly. If children mispronounce a word, repeat the sentence after them, using the correct word rather than correcting them explicitly.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need the pretend vocabulary card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In Preschool Time, the children in the preschool play with pretend money.
Today we learned the word pretend.
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Use the pretend Vocabulary Card to review the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of different things. Some of these things are pretend and some of them are real. You will look at each picture and say if you think what you see is pretend or real.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Identify the Object Before children start identifying which object is pretend or real, have them identify what the object in the picture is.
Ask Show one picture card and use the text on the back to ask if the object in the picture is pretend or real. Why or why not? Offer extra support or challenge as needed.
Sort Have children sort the pictures into “pretend things” and “real things.”
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Talk About It Talk together about which objects are real versus pretend. Ask children if it was hard to figure out which object was real.
Have children describe the object in the picture. Looking closely at and describing the object might help children figure out which object is pretend versus which item is real.

Encourage children to identify examples in the classroom of pretend objects. Have them use complete sentences. For example, “This is a pretend kitchen.” Then talk about the real version of that object.

The classroom is a great place to show children that the language that they speak at home is valued, and that they know something that others, including the teacher, may not know. Ask children if they know how to say any of the objects they see in the pictures in another language. Have them teach one word to you and the rest of the class.

Oral language activities provide a good opportunity for all children to excel. Encourage children to act out the scene in the book where the characters are playing with pretend money. Ask children to talk about what they are doing. Encourage as much conversation as possible.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we learned about school rules such as “listening to the teacher” and “taking turns.”
In this activity, we will look at different pictures and tell if the picture shows something that we do at school or something that we do away from school.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.

Talk About School Have children talk about their favorite things to do at school. Encourage children to discuss different categories, such as favorite songs, favorite subjects, favorite games, and favorite books. Invite children to think about things they do both at school and away from school.
Encourage children to describe each activity they see in the pictures before they try to decide if it’s something they do at school or away from school.
Encourage children to name what we do at different times of the day. For example: “What do we do before lunch?” Have children use complete sentences. For example: “We sing songs before lunch.”

The classroom is a great place to show children that the language they speak at home is valued, and that they know something that others, including the teacher, may not know. Ask children if they know how to say any of the activities they see in the pictures in another language. Have them teach one expression to you and the rest of the class.

Helping children focus their attention is a critical learning milestone for preschoolers. You can help children focus their attention through a variety of strategies, including using simple directions and previewing each activity before you begin. Model what to do with each card and check to make sure that all children know what to do.
